channel.title: Stars
channel.description: Various stars and double stars in our galaxy.

item.title: Albireo - colorful double star.
item.description: Albireo, a colorful double star in the constellation Cygnus. 30 sec exposure with the Canon T5i on the Celestron 11-inch.
item.media:description: Albireo, a colorful double star in the constellation Cygnus. 30 sec exposure with the Canon T5i on the Celestron 11-inch.

item.title: Alcor and Mizar
item.description: 25 second exposure of the blue stars Alcor (bottom) and Mizar (top). One can tell that Mizar is at least 2 stars. It is actually at least 4 stars. Alcor and Mizar are a visual double in the handle of the Big Dipper asterism.
item.media:description: 25 second exposure of the blue stars Alcor (bottom) and Mizar (top). One can tell that Mizar is at least 2 stars. It is actually at least 4 stars. Alcor and Mizar are a visual double in the handle of the Big Dipper asterism.

item.title: Capella in Auriga
item.description: 15 second exposure of the bright star Capella in the constellation Auriga. Taken with the Canon T5i on the 11-inch Celestron
item.media:description: 15 second exposure of the bright star Capella in the constellation Auriga. Taken with the Canon T5i on the 11-inch Celestron

item.title: Castor in Gemini
item.description: The star Castor in color. This is a sextuple star system. The orange star to the left contains two of the stars, while the other 4 stars (center) are too close together to resolve in this photo.
item.media:description: The star Castor in color. This is a sextuple star system. The orange star to the left contains two of the stars, while the other 4 stars (center) are too close together to resolve in this photo.

item.title: Castor - short exposure
item.description: A shorter exposure of Castor revealing the two main clumps of stars which are about 4 arcseconds apart. 1/30 second taken with the Canon T5i on the 11-inch Celestron.
item.media:description: A shorter exposure of Castor revealing the two main clumps of stars which are about 4 arcseconds apart. 1/30 second taken with the Canon T5i on the 11-inch Celestron.

item.title: Eta Cassiopeiae
item.description: Eta Cassiopeiae is a double star in the constellation Cassiopeia with a separation of 12 arcseconds. This binary star system is about 20 lightyears away from us. The brighter, yellower star is much like our Sun, while the slightly redder star is a bit less massive.
item.media:description: Eta Cassiopeiae is a double star in the constellation Cassiopeia with a separation of 12 arcseconds. This binary star system is about 20 lightyears away from us. The brighter, yellower star is much like our Sun, while the slightly redder star is a bit less massive.

item.title: Iota Cancri - double star
item.description: Iota Cancri, a colorful double star in Cancer. Canon T5i on Celestron C11.
item.media:description: Iota Cancri, a colorful double star in Cancer. Canon T5i on Celestron C11.

item.title: Procyon - a bright star.
item.description: The star Procyon in Canis Minor. One of the brightest stars in the winter sky, but outshined by nearby Sirius in Canis Major. Stacked exposure taken with the SVbony 305 pro guide camera.
item.media:description: The star Procyon in Canis Minor. One of the brightest stars in the winter sky, but outshined by nearby Sirius in Canis Major. Stacked exposure taken with the SVbony 305 pro guide camera.
